cards.meaning: Brief and to the point; Effectively cut short.
cards.example: Jessica is so talkative that her sister thought the situation warrated conciseness and her being laconic.

cards.meaning: Lacking taste or flavor
cards.example: Too much sugar makes this otherwise delightful fruit pie insipid.

cards.meaning: Concerned with practical matters
cards.example: After five years of war, both sides have found pragmatic ways to make peace with one another, as the bloodshed has grown viscous and brutal.

cards.meaning: someone who attacks cherished beliefs or institutions
cards.example: He is often seen as a rebel, an iconoclast who follows his own rules.

cards.meaning: involving or requiring strenuous effort; difficult and tiring.
cards.example: In those days, a trip to the West was an arduous journey.

cards.meaning: recklessly extravagant or wasteful in use of resources
cards.example: Spending £13,000 on a handbag seems offensively profligate.

cards.meaning: without interest, imagination, and excitement; dull;
cards.example: He asked if I'd got my black eye in a fight - I told him the prosaic truth that I'd banged my head on a door.

cards.meaning: to make a bad or unpleasant situation better
cards.example: Foreign aid is badly needed to ameliorate the effects of the drought.

cards.meaning: too eager to praise or obey someone; excessively obedient
cards.example: She is embarrassingly obsequious to anyone in authority.

cards.meaning: likely to change, or reacting to a sudden desire or new idea
cards.example: The decision rejected the notion of an arbitrary and capricious power accruing to state securities commissioners.

cards.meaning: happening by chance rather than intention; fortunate
cards.example: The collapse of its rivals was a fortuitous opportunity for the company.

cards.meaning: conforming to all the traditional beliefs, and religious practices; acceptable
cards.example: Orthodox strategies for socio-economic development in developing countries.

cards.meaning: lively and cheerful readiness; eagerness
cards.example: I am sure that they will be accepted with alacrity, knowing my noble friend's expertise in such matters.

cards.meaning: very clear and shining; very clear in meaning and easy to understand
cards.example: the pellucid light of a spring morning.

cards.meaning: confirm or give support to; add information to an idea
cards.example: Recent research seems to corroborate the theory.

cards.meaning: very kind and generous towards someone you have defeated; forgiving
cards.example: The team's manager was magnanimous in victory, and praised the losing team.

cards.meaning: diligent; thorough; honest; extremely careful
cards.example: The nurse told him to be scrupulous about keeping the wound clean.

cards.meaning: producing a great number or amount of something; fruitful
cards.example: Harada has been prolific, releasing more than 70 singles.

cards.meaning: opinionated; strongly expressing your beliefs as if they were facts;
cards.example: If you are dogmatic, you are certain that you are right and that everyone else is wrong.

cards.meaning: to stop someone from feeling angry or hostile.
cards.example: Outraged minority groups will not be placated by promises of future improvements.

cards.meaning: changing suddenly and often; temperamental
cards.example: She was entertaining but unpredictable, with mercurial mood swings.

cards.meaning: make something already bad, worse; infuriate;
cards.example: This attack will exacerbate the already tense relations between the two communities.

cards.meaning: unnecessary because it is more than is needed; superfluous
cards.example: In the sentence "She is a single unmarried woman", the word "unmarried" is redundant.

cards.meaning: Unoriginal; Trite; Tedious and uninspiring
cards.example: The plot of the film is just a hackneyed boy-meets-girl scenario.

cards.meaning: careful and avoiding risks; showing care and thought
cards.example: It's always prudent to read a contract carefully before signing it.

cards.meaning: to show something to be false, or to hide something such as an emotion.
cards.example: Her calm face belied the terror she was feeling.

cards.meaning: intended for or understood by only a few people who have special knowledge; obscure
cards.example: Literary readings can sometimes seem esoteric, but we are trying to make them more attractive to more people.

cards.meaning: an unpleasant mixture of loud sounds
cards.example: The cacophony surrounding the multi-billion dollar buyout of leading messaging service by a social networking company shook the whole tech industry.

cards.meaning: likely to do something suddenly, without considering the results of your actions
cards.example: He's so impetuous - why can't he think things over before he rushes into them?

cards.meaning: a strange or unusual habit, way of behaving, or feature
cards.example: One of the idiosyncrasies of this printer is that you can't stop it once it has started.

cards.meaning: used to refer to something very old that is still existing
cards.example: Phyllis Wheatley is the author of the earliest extant volume of poetry by an African American.

cards.meaning: not clear and difficult to understand or see; not known to many people
cards.example: Official policy has changed, for reasons that remain obscure.

cards.meaning: intended to teach, especially in a way that is too determined or eager, and often fixed and unwilling to change
cards.example: Children’s books possess a practical, didactic purpose – to instill a love for reading.

cards.meaning: brief; to the point;  expressing an idea cleverly in a few words.
cards.example: He was considered a superb and pithy writer.

cards.meaning: in large amounts, or more than enough
cards.example: He took copious notes during the lecture.

cards.meaning: a vulgar show of wealth, possessions, or power intended to attract admiration or notice; show-off
cards.example: Her luxurious lifestyle and personal ostentation were both hated and envied.

cards.meaning: alter or debase often for profit; to make something weaker or of worse quality by adding something else to it
cards.example: Saffron is very expensive, and is often adulterated with other plants.

cards.meaning: loud and clamorous
cards.example: Local activist groups have become increasingly vociferous as the volume of traffic passing through the village has increased.

cards.meaning: tending not to speak much; reserved; uncommunicative in speech
cards.example: He was always quiet, reserved, and taciturn.

cards.meaning: extremely determined to act in a particular way and not to change despite what anyone else says; stubborn
cards.example: Union leaders remain obdurate that working conditions and pay improve.

cards.meaning: excessively talkative; having the habit of talking a lot, especially about things that are not important
cards.example: I had talked too much about myself and felt like a garrulous old fool.

cards.meaning: someone who dislikes or hates and avoids other people
cards.example: He is a hard-cursing, chain-smoking misanthrope who formerly worked on a children's television programme.

cards.meaning: to make someone famous, or to treat someone as if they were famous
cards.example: During her reign he was much lionized as a military hero of incredible valor.

cards.meaning: about to happen
cards.example: He gave a dire warning that an earthquake was imminent.

cards.meaning: to laugh at someone or something in a way that shows you think they are stupid or of no value; insult
cards.example: This building, once derided by critics, is now a major tourist attraction.

cards.meaning: lazy; sluggish;  feeling unwilling and unable to do anything
cards.example: He was found to be pale, thin, wasted and lethargic, with slow and confused answers, according to the hospital's discharge summary.

cards.meaning: only recently or partly formed, or not completely developed or clear; undeveloped;
cards.example: He is easily intimidated when the left condemns this vague, inchoate mixture of family loyalty and patriotism as the bigotry of the extreme right.

cards.meaning: felt or experienced very strongly or in an extreme way; thoughtful
cards.example: The invention of the contraceptive pill brought about profound changes in the lives of women.

cards.meaning: a person who is too interested in formal rules and small details that are not important
cards.example: Harrison is a pedant who would rather waste his time bickering than letting trivial things go.

cards.meaning: extreme happiness, sometimes more than is reasonable in a particular situation
cards.example: The cricket team players where euphoric after their world cup victory.

cards.meaning: something that is mysterious and seems impossible or difficult to understand completely
cards.example: The newspapers were full of stories about the enigma of the plane's disappearance.

cards.meaning: having two opposing feelings at the same time, or being uncertain about how you feel; conflicting
cards.example: I felt very ambivalent about leaving home.

cards.meaning: to be uncertain what to do, or to change often between two opinions; be indecisive
cards.example: Her mood vacillated between hope and despair.

cards.meaning: ​weak and cowardly (= not brave); frightened of taking risks; fearful;
cards.example: He's too pusillanimous to stand up to his opponents.

cards.meaning: ​lasting for only a short time; momentary; passing
cards.example: Fame in the world of rock and pop is largely ephemeral.

cards.meaning: ​(of a person) unwilling to obey orders or to do what should be done, or (of an animal) refusing to be controlled
cards.example: Tenants petitioned their recalcitrant landlord to finish repairs to their building.

cards.meaning: ​giving too much attention to small details and wanting everything to be correct and perfect;​
cards.example: He is very fastidious about how a suitcase should be packed.

cards.meaning: ​ more than is needed or wanted; unnecessary
cards.example: The report was marred by a mass of superfluous detail.

cards.meaning: ​harmful; limiting
cards.example: Excessive managerial control is inimical to creative expression.

cards.meaning: ​to speak in a way that is intentionally not clear and confusing to other people, especially to hide the truth
cards.example: She accused the minister of equivocating, claiming that he had deliberately avoided telling the public how bad the problem really was.
